articles.headline: High-Density Living Reduces Carbon Footprint 40%
articles.summary: Urban efficiency beats suburban sprawl on all sustainability metrics.
articles.content: MIT urban planning research shows dense cities use 40% less energy per capita. Public transit viability increases with density. Green space more efficiently utilized. Economic productivity higher in concentrated areas. Infrastructure costs lower per resident.

articles.headline: Suburban Living Provides Better Quality of Life
articles.summary: Studies show health and happiness higher outside dense cities.
articles.content: Journal of Urban Health found suburban residents report 25% higher life satisfaction. Children perform better academically with yard space. Mental health improves with lower density. Crime rates significantly lower. Home ownership more achievable.

articles.headline: Rent Control Keeps 100,000 Families Housed in NYC
articles.summary: Policy prevents displacement and maintains community stability.
articles.content: Columbia University study shows rent control prevents gentrification displacement. Long-term residents maintain community bonds. Teachers, firefighters can afford to live where they work. Neighborhood diversity preserved. Housing remains affordable for working families.

articles.headline: Rent Control Reduces Housing Supply by 15%
articles.summary: Economists warn policy worsens affordability crisis.
articles.content: Stanford economists found rent control decreased rental supply 15% in San Francisco. Landlords convert to condos or Airbnb. Maintenance deferred on controlled units. New construction discouraged. Overall rents increase for non-controlled units.

articles.headline: Housing Solutions Require Multiple Policy Tools
articles.content: Urban Institute review shows no single policy solves housing crisis. Supply increases, affordability programs, zoning reform all needed. Different cities require different solutions. Public-private partnerships show promise. Context determines effective strategy.
